description: This lecture and laboratory course covers concepts of Cellular Biochemistry, Microbiology and Molecular Genetics basic to an understanding of the fundamental processes of living organisms. The organization and characteristics of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, structural and functional relationships of the major biomolecules, interrelationships of the various metabolic pathways, basics of molecular genetics and immunology are covered.
name: INTRODUCTION TO MICROBIOLOGY AND HUMAN BIOCHEMISTRY

section.name: INTRODUCTION TO MICROBIOLOGY AND HUMAN BIOCHEMISTRY

values.comments:
This lecture and laboratory course covers concepts of Cellular Biochemistry, Microbiology and Molecular Genetics basic to an understanding of the fundamental processes of living organisms. The organization and characteristics of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, structural and functional relationships of the major biomolecules, interrelationships of the various metabolic pathways, basics of molecular genetics and immunology. Lectures were co-taught by Professors Lafferty and Pohlschroder. This course is cross-listed as BIOL042 and BIOL175.

Overall, students found lectures to be “interesting” and “engaging” but “very challenging.” Almost all students agreed that they learned a great deal in the course. One student even wrote that “This is the one class at Penn in which I actually learned Biology and remember it.”

Students called Professor Lafferty “an amazing instructor,” though sometimes hard to keep up with. Students commented that both professors were willing to answer questions after class and seemed very knowledgeable about the material. The professors were able to make the topics relevant to the nursing profession.

Students, overall, found this class difficult, commenting that exam questions did not seem to correspond with what was emphasized (or even taught) during lecture and reviews. Also, many students had difficulty keeping up since the course covered such an enormous amount of detailed information. This course has the following prerequisites: CHEM 101, CHEM 053, CHEM 102, CHEM 054 or NURS 040. 3 h. lect. 4 h. lab. 1 h. rec. Lab fee $100. All nursing students are required to complete this course as part of the major requirements.
